comments:
Entitled Cellular Biology and Biochemistry, BIOL 202 has BIOL 101 and 102, or BIOL 121 as prerequisites. A strong high school background in chemistry or CHEM 102 is recommended. This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity, as well as an introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.

This course was described as enjoyable, but challenging, with one student calling it his favorite biology course at Penn. The “interesting material” is “useful for anyone in the life sciences,” although the most common complaint among students is that the course material is too similar to BIOL 121. Students highly recommend the class for biology majors, and warn to be prepared for “lots of memorization.”

This course is taught by two different professors. Professor Guo was described as very “passionate and knowledgeable” about the course material, but students unanimously agreed that it is very difficult to understand Professor Guo’s accent, making his lectures more difficult than the other professor’s. Of the two professors, Dr. Guo emphasizes general concepts and application. His exam questions were also described as “vague.”

The exams for BIOL 202 are “tricky and detailed,” as well as “inconsistent in style and difficulty,” making it hard to prepare for the exams or anticipate the nature of the questions. Students also felt that the curve for this course was very difficult.

Entitled Cellular Biology and Biochemistry, BIOL 202 has BIOL 101 and 102, or BIOL 121 as prerequisites. A strong high school background in chemistry or CHEM 102 is recommended. This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity, as well as an introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.

This course was described as enjoyable, but challenging, with one student calling it his favorite biology course at Penn. The “interesting material” is “useful for anyone in the life sciences,” although the most common complaint among students is that the course material is too similar to BIOL 121. Students highly recommend the class for biology majors, and warn to be prepared for “lots of memorization.”

This course is taught by two different professors. Student’s praised Dr. Gregory’s teaching style, calling him “fantastic” and an “absolutely amazing professor.” Dr. Gregory does a “great job of communicating” the course material, and his lectures were described as not only “stimulating,” but also “easy to follow and understand.”

The exams for BIOL 202 are “tricky and detailed,” as well as “inconsistent in style and difficulty,” making it hard to prepare for the exams or anticipate the nature of the questions. Students also felt that the curve for this course was very difficult.

This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.

This course is rich in content. It enforces critical thinking skills. Many students enjoyed the in-class problems.

Students found that the videos and in-class problems Professor Witmer used made the class less static, and a nice break from lecture. Professor Witmer was described as a great lecturer but had trouble understanding and responding to questions that were asked. Dr. Witmer really cares about her students understanding of the material and is willing to offer outside help. At times, she struggles to garner interest, but is very clear as to what topics are important to know in the long term.

The prerequisites for this course include BIOL 101 and 102, or BIOL 121. In addition, a strong high school background in chemistry or CHEM 102 is recommended. Students found that the questions on the exams were difficult to understand. The questions were posed in a confusing and convoluted manner and more effort was placed on understanding what the questions were asking rather than answering them.
